item.title: Self-assembling Carbon nano tubes via Teslacoil
item.description:
Self-assembling Carbon nano tubes via Teslacoil

Nikola Tesla conjured up all sorts of interesting experiments for his famed "Tesla Coils." Today, however, their main use has been relegated largely to impressing visitors at science museums. That is about to change. Researchers at Rice University have used Tesla coils to get carbon nanotubes to self-assemble into long chains, a phenomenon the scientists have dubbed "Teslaphoresis."

item.title: SCHAFT Unveils Awesome New Bipedal Robot at Japan Conference
item.description:
SCHAFT Unveils Awesome New Bipedal Robot at Japan Conference

Right now, the New Economic Summit (NEST) 2016 conference is going on in Tokyo, Japan. One of the keynote speakers is Andy Rubin. Rubin was in charge of Google's robotics program in 2013, when the company (now Alphabet) acquired a fistful of some of the most capable and interesting robotics companies in the world.

item.title: The chips are down for Moore's law
item.description:
The chips are down for Moore's law

Next month, the worldwide semiconductor industry will formally acknowledge what has become increasingly obvious to everyone involved: Moore's law, the principle that has powered the information-technology revolution since the 1960s, is nearing its end.
